newsitem.title: HONG KONG: ASIAN DEBT MARKETS - Dull but deals developing.
newsitem.headline: ASIAN DEBT MARKETS - Dull but deals developing.

text.p: Asian debt markets were extremely slow on Thursday, with no new launches to report.
There were some new developments, however.
Bank of China officials today said they are considering a dollar bond issue, but declined to give a timetable or an amount for the issue.
"We are always following the market to see whether we should issue a Yankee bond," one bank official said.
"As regards to short term, we have not yet reached any decision," he said.
Bankers said State Development Bank of China is taking bids on its Yankee issue. The state-held policy bank said in June that it planned to seek about US$300 million in funding abroad.
There also have been reports that Guangdong International Trust and Investment Corp is mulling a dollar bond.

In the Hong Kong market, bankers said Dah Sing Bank is taking bids for a HK$1 billion borrowing. The issue is expected to be eligible for the Hong Kong Monetary Authority's Liquidity Adjustment Facility (LAF), or discount window.
Eligibility for LAF makes an issue more attractive to banks because holders of the qualifying debt can engage in repurchase agreements with the monetary authority, increasing liquidity.

Earlier this year, there was some speculation that Dao Heng Bank might issue another LAF-eligible FRCD, but bankers noted that Guoco Group, which holds a large share of Dao Heng Bank, recenly issued a US$180 million floating rate note.
On the loan side, a Hong Kong property consortium is seeking bids on a HK$6.4 billion facility to finance a residential redevelopment project in Hong Kong's Pokfulam district.
Bids will be taken on three proposals that differ in the way the guarantee is structured.

In other debt news, Standard and Poor's Corp revised the rating outlook of Reliance Industries to positive from stable. Bankers said Reliance mandated a 150 million Sterling 10-year bond issue to HSBC Markets several months ago.
